questions.question: Which of the following is an uncommon etiology for prolapse?
What is the most important support of the pelvic viscera?
questions.explanation: The most important support of the pelvic viscera is the levator ani muscle. The levator ani forms alarge portion of the pelvic floor. It is composed of three separate paired muscles:•⚫ Pubococcygeus⚫ Puborectalis•• IliococcygeusSupports of the genital organs are given by DeLancey's levels of support. However, the broadligament is a fold of the peritoneum, which doesn't provide support to pelvic organs.

questions.question: A woman presented to you with the following finding. Which of the following is not a riskfactor for this condition?591
questions.explanation: 599The given image shows uterine prolapse, for which an episiotomy is not a risk factor.Episiotomy shortens the second stage of labor and prevents the atonicity of the uterus, thusreducing the risk of prolapse.The risk factors for uterine prolapse are:• Pregnancy• Vaginal delivery• Menopause•Aging• Hypoestrogenism• Peripheral nerve injury to the pudendal nerve• Premature bearing down before full dilatation of the cervix• Chronically increased intra-abdominal pressure• Chronic bronchitis•Constipation•Obesity•Spina bifida occulta•Congenital weakness of pelvic floor muscles• Abdominoperineal excision of rectum•Surgeries such as Stamey and Pereyra operation for stress incontinence

questions.question: A 64-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic with complaints of a mass descendingPV. On examination, you note that the external os lies at the level of the introitus. What is thedegree of uterine prolapse?
questions.explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of 2nd degree prolapse.Degrees of uterine prolapseNormalDescent of cervixup to introituCarviVaginaDescent of cervixinto vaginaDescent of cervixoutside introitusProcidentia (All of the uterusoutside the introitus)<OMARROW600

questions.question: Which of the following is correctly matched between classification systems of prolapse andtheir reference point?
questions.explanation: In Baden-Walker halfway system of classification of prolapse, the reference point is the hymen.Prolapse classification systeReference poimntShawsIntroitusBaden Walker halfwayPOP-QHymenHymen

questions.question: Which of the following is seen in congenital elongation of the cervix?

options.A: The vaginal portion of the cervix gets elongated
options.B: The supravaginal portion of the cervix gets elongated
options.C: Both the vaginal and supravaginal portions of the cervix get elongated
options.D: There is no true elongation and it is a misnomer592

questions.explanation: In congenital elongation of the cervix, the vaginal portion of the cervix is elongated. The fornicesare hence deep, and there is no accompanying vaginal prolapse.In 2nd and 3rd degree uterine prolapse, the supravaginal portion of the cervix gets stretched andelongated as it is well supported by the Mackenrodt's ligaments, while the vaginal portion of thecervix prolapses with the vagina. In prolapse, the cervix can elongate to as much as 10cm inlength.However, in procidentia, the entire uterus slides with the vagina, and hence the cervix retains itsnormal length.

questions.question: Which of the following differential diagnosis will you not consider in a case of prolapse?
questions.explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of uterine prolapse. A retroverted uterus is not a differentialdiagnosis for uterine prolapse.However, retroversion of the uterus does occur with uterine prolapse.Differential diagnoses of genital prolapse include:Congenital elongation of the cervix - vaginal part of the cervix is elongated. In genital prolapse,supravaginal part is elongated and vaginal part is prolapsed.• Vulval cyst and Gartner cyst - large cysts may mimic prolapse•Cyst of the anterior vaginal wall - tense with well-defined margins and cannot be reduced onpressure.•• Urethral diverticula - rare, small, and situated low in the anterior vaginal wall. Urethroscopyhelps in the diagnosis.• Cervical fibroid polyp - cervix remains high up in its anatomical position.601⚫ Chronic inversion of the uterus - Uterine sound is used to confirm the diagnosis. USG and•laparoscopy will show fundal depression and the absence of uterine fundus in the pelvis.• Rectal prolapse

questions.question: A 57-year-old woman presents to you with complaints of mass descending per vaginum forthe past 6 months. On examination, grade 3 uterovaginal prolapse and a decubitus ulcer areobserved. What causes this ulcer?
questions.explanation: Decubitus ulcer seen in uterine prolapse is due to venous congestion and local circulatorychanges.Decubitus ulcer refers to the ulceration of prolapsed tissue which occurs due to the chronicdependent position causing venous congestion and stasis. It has a clean edge and usually healswell with prolapse reduction and daily packing with glycerine (hygroscopic agent) and acriflavine(antiseptic). It is a benign and non-infectious disease and does not require further investigationsuch as biopsy or culture.

questions.question: A post-menopausal woman presents with a mass protruding from the vagina that increases insize on coughing and sneezing. Which of the following is not a complication of this condition?
questions.explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of pelvic organ prolapse. Urge incontinence is not acomplication of this condition.Complications of prolapse are:• Damage to the ureter - can occur during•Surgical repair• Kinking due to procidentia• Urinary tract infection - due to retention of urine in a cystocele• Hydronephrosis and hydroureter• Incarceration of the prolapse - the prolapsed organ becomes irreducible•• Decubitus ulcer• Stress incontinence•Squamous cell carcinoma over the decubitus ulcer (rare)

questions.question: A multiparous woman notices a bulge at the vulva that diminishes in size on lying down. Shealso finds it difficult to initiate micturition. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of a cystocoele.A cystocele is the herniation of the urinary bladder into the vagina. It is usually associated withuterine prolapse, and presents with the following features:• Mass descending in the vagina -•Increases in size on straining and coughing602• Reduces on lying down, or manual reduction• Difficulty in micturition - difficulty initiating, straining required•• Mass needs to be pushed inwards to urinate - repositioning of cystocele required•Increased frequency of micturition• Backache due to stretching of uterosacral ligaments-

questions.question: Which of the following is correct about the POP-Q staging system?

options.A: Stage 4 involves complete eversion of the vagina.
options.B: In stage 3, the leading point is 1 cm above hymen.
options.C: Five reference points are present in the vagina.
options.D: The points above the hymen are described as plus.

questions.explanation: The Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification (POP-Q) system was described by the InternationalContinence Society and has the following features:• The hymen is taken as a fixed point.●Six reference points are measured, using a scaled spatula:• Two on the anterior vaginal wall•Two on the apical vagina• Two on the posterior vaginal wall• Three measurements: The genital hiatus, perineal body, and total vaginal length.•The points above the hymen are described as minus and points below as plus.Staging of pelvic organ prolapse according to the POP-Q system:StagDescriptionStage oNo descent of pelvic organsStag The leading edge of the prolae 1Stage 2Stage 3Stage 4pse is>1 cm abovethe level ofthehymen.The leading edge of the prolapse is<1 cmproximal or distalto the hymen.The leading point of prolapseis>1 cm belowthehymenbutprotrudes no further than 2 cm less than the total length of the vagina.Completeeversionof the vagina6033 cmAaBaPelvic organ prolapsequantification system (POP-Q)BaAaApBpGenitalhiatus (gh)Perinealbody (pb)Point A anteriorD-Point B anteriorCervix or vaginal cuffApBpPosterior fornixPoint A posteriorPoint B posteriorMARROW

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman presents with pelvic pain, and a mass descending PV with increases insize on coughing. She is posted for a Fothergill repair. Which of the following is false aboutthis procedure?

options.A: It is also known as Manchester operation
options.B: It does not preserve the reproductive functions
options.C: Recurrent abortions are a sequelae of this operation

questions.explanation: Fothergill's operation preserves menstrual and reproductive functions.Fothergill's repair is also known as Manchester's operation. It is suitable for women under 40years who are desirous of retaining their menstrual and reproductive functions. The steps are:•• Preliminary D and C•Anterior colporrhaphy with amputation of the cervix.• Raw area covered with the vaginal mucosa.• Mackenrodt ligaments sutured in the front of the cervix• ColpoperineorrhaphySince the uterus is preserved in this procedure, the patient is able to menstruate and can conceiveand carry the pregnancy. However, fertility decreases due to the loss of cervical mucus. Moreover,cervical incompetence occurs, leading to recurrent abortions and preterm deliveries.604Manchester's/Fothergill's procedureCardinal ligaments sutured in front of the cervixOMARROWCervixAmputatedShirodkar's modification of Fothergill's repair avoids cervical amputation, hence subsequentpregnancy complications are avoided.Shirodkar's procedureCardinal ligaments sutured on each side of the cervixMARROWCervixpreserved

questions.question: A 55-year-old lady presents with third degree uterine prolapse. Which of the following is thebest management for her?

options.C: Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair

questions.explanation: In the clinal scenario of a 55-year-old woman with third-degree uterine prolapse, the idealmanagement is vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair.Uterine prolapse is the descent of the uterus from its normal position which usually occurs due tolaxity of ligaments that offer support, seen often due to childbirth, aging, or trauma. The uterinedescent is clinically categorized into:•• First degree: the external os remains above the vaginal introitus605• Second degree: The external os protrudes below the vaginal introitus but the uterine bodyremains inside the vagina• Third degree (Syn: Complete prolapse): The uterine, cervix, body, and fundus descend to lieoutside the introitus•Procidentia involves prolapse of the uterus with the entire vagina everted.The patient usually presents with a sense of heaviness in the pelvic region with lower backdiscomfort. Based on the structures involved the patient can additionally have urinary symptoms(like incontinence and urgency), bowel disturbances (constipation and tenesmus), or sexualdiscomfort during intercourse.Symptomatic uterine prolapse is managed surgically with different procedures based on theprofile of the patient. Conservative management is done for old asymptomatic women with milddegree prolapse.A vaginal hysterectomy is recommended for patients who satisfy the following criteria:• >40 years of age• Have completed their families• Do not wish to preserve menstrual and child-bearing functionOther options:Option A: Fothergill repair or Manchester operation is a procedure done to preserve thereproductive function and vaginal prolapse with supravaginal cervix elongation. It initiallyinvolves preliminary curettage with low amputation of the cervix. After Mackenrodt's ligament isplicated, anterior colporrhaphy and colpoperineorrhaphy are performed.Option B: Sling operation (Purandare's operation) is indicated in congenital or nulliparousprolapse without cystocele. The procedure involves the extraperitoneal passage of rectus sheathstrips joined to the anterior surface of the cervix by silk sutures.Option D: Shirodkar procedure is a type of abdominal sling surgery done in young women toretain menstrual and reproductive function. It involves using a sling to fix the cervix to thelumbosacral fascia.

questions.question: A 75-year-old woman diagnosed with procidentia is posted for operative repair. During apre-anesthetic check-up, she was determined to be medically unfit for major surgery. Whichof the following procedures is recommended in her?594
questions.explanation: Le Fort's repair is recommended in this case. This repair is done in patients who satisfy thefollowing criteria:•Elderly (>60 years)• Do not wish to retain sexual function• Medically unfit for major surgeries

questions.question: A 25-year-old nulliparous woman presents to you with primary infertility. On examination,stage 2 uterine prolapse is present. What is the next step in management?
questions.explanation: 606Sling operations are recommended in cases of nulliparous prolapse, who wish to retain menstrualand child-bearing functionMackenrodt's and uterosacral ligaments of the uterus are strengthened, by using nylon or Dacrontapes as slings. Abdominal sling operations include:• Abdominal wall cervicopexy - cervical supports are fixed to the abdominal wall• Shirodkar's sling operation - cervix is fixed to the lumbosacral fascia using Mersilene tape• Khanna's abdominal sling operation - isthmus of the cervix is fixed to the anterior superior iliacspines. It is not done anymore due to the risk of periosteitis.• Virkud's sling operation - the tape is fixed from the isthmus and attached to the rectuscompartment•⚫ Joshi's sling operation - the uterus is suspended from the pectineal ligaments.

questions.question: A 67-year-old woman diagnosed with uterine prolapse, now presented with dyspareunia andfecal incontinence. After manually reducing the prolapse, a peristaltic bulge is seen in theposterior vaginal wall. What is the preferred method of management in this case?
questions.explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of an enterocele associated with fecal incontinence. It ispreferably repaired using an abdominal approach like Moschcowitz repair.An enterocele is herniation of the pouch of Douglas and small bowel loops into the rectovaginalseptum. Enteroceles are most commonly associated with uterine prolapse. Patients present withthe following clinical features:• Fecal incontinence• Sexual dysfunction• Constipation/diarrhea• Mass descending PV• Pelvic pain or pelvic discomfort•A bulge in the posterior vaginal wall:• Upper 1/3rd - enterocele• Lower 2/3rd - rectocele• Peristalsis may be observed in the bulgeEnterocele repair is done via the following methods:• Vaginal approach - it is usually preferred over an abdominal approach. In McCall'sculdoplasty, the uterosacral ligaments are used to suspend the vaginal vault. The posteriorperitoneum and uterosacral ligaments are approximated.• Abdominal approach - it is preferred in cases where there is associated fecal incontinence. Itincludes:•Moschcowitz repair - the pouch of Douglas is obliterated by several purse-string sutures.• Halban's procedure - the peritoneal sac is obliterated using vertical sutures. This can also bedone transvaginally.607Option B: Purandare's sling operation is abdominal wall cervicopexy for uterine prolapse. It isdone for young nulliparous women.Option D: Le Fort's repair is done in elderly patients with uterine prolapse, who are unfit forsurgery.Note: Enteroceles may be present along with uterine prolapse. Failure to identify and repair itduring vaginal hysterectomy can lead to vault prolapse.

questions.question: How many degrees of vault prolapse are there?
questions.explanation: There are 3 degrees of vault prolapse.Vault prolapse is a delayed complication of both abdominal and vaginal hysterectomy. It can alsooccur due to failure to identify and repair an enterocele during a hysterectomy.In vault prolapse, level 1 supports become weak and deficient. Risk factors apart from past historyof surgery are:• Advanced age• Menopause - due to estrogen deficiency• Parity• Obesity• Chronic cough

questions.question: 595A 55-year-old woman presented with a mass bulging into the vagina, difficult intercourse, andback pain. She has a history of hysterectomy 2 years back. On examination, you observe thatthe vaginal vault is protruding outside the introitus. What is the best management in thiscase?
questions.explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of vault prolapse. Sacrospinous colpopexy is the goldstandard management for vault prolapse.Vault prolapse presents with pelvic or back pain, the descent of the vault through the vagina,difficulties in intercourse, and difficulty in walking due to the mass. It is commonly associatedwith a cystocele or a rectocele.It can be prevented by identifying and repairing an enterocele and by attaching the uterosacraland cardinal ligaments to the vault during a hysterectomy.Vault prolapse is managed as follows:••If the patient is fit for abdominal surgery: Transabdominal sacral colpopexy, i.e., uterosacralsuspension••If the patient is not fit for abdominal surgery: Transvaginal sacrospinous ligamentfixation/colpopexy - the gold standard• Laparoscopic colpopexyIf the patient does not want to retain sexual function:• Colpocleisis608•Le Fort's repair• Anterior colporrhaphy in case of cystocele.⚫ Posterior colporrhaphy in case of rectocele••If the patient is unfit for surgery, ring pessaries can be tried⚫ Posterior intravaginal slingplastyNote: Kelly's repair and Burch colposuspension are done to manage stress incontinence.

questions.question: A young woman with uterine prolapse following pelvic trauma underwent a hysterectomy. Ayear later, she presents with vault prolapse. What would you not recommend for her?
questions.explanation: In a young patient with vault prolapse, ring pessary is not recommended.Vault prolapse is managed as follows:• If the patient is fit for abdominal surgery: Transabdominal sacral colpopexy, i.e., uterosacralsuspension - The best method for vault prolapse.•• If the patient is not fit for abdominal surgery: Transvaginal sacrospinous ligament fixation.• Laparoscopic colpopexy•If the patient does not want to retain sexual function:• Colpocleisis⚫Le Fort's repair• Anterior colporrhaphy in case of cystocele• Posterior colporrhaphy in case of rectocele• If the patient is unfit for surgery, ring pessaries can be tried•⚫ Posterior intravaginal slingplasty

questions.question: The given instrument was used to treat a patient with uterine prolapse. Which of thefollowing statements is false about this instrument?596

options.A: It should be changed every 3 months.
options.B: It can be used in pregnant patients.
options.D: It may rarely cause carcinoma of vagina.

questions.explanation: The given image shows a ring pessary, which is only a palliative treatment for genital prolapse.A ring pessary is used for patients who cannot be surgically managed, such as pregnant patientsand very elderly women. In these patients, it is used as an adjunct to pelvic floor physiotherapy.Pessaries provide mechanical support to the pelvic organs. After being placed, they should bechanged every 3 months. They may cause vaginitis; dyspareunia; and, rarely, carcinoma ifretained for a long time.The image below shows the types of pessaries:609Types of pessariesDoughnut pessaryRing pessary with supportGellhorn pessaryMARROW

questions.question: Which of the following is the first step after fitting the pessary to check if the pessary isadequately retained?

options.A: Asking the patient to void and see if the pessary is in place
options.B: Seeing if the patient feels any discomfort, which means that the pessary is retained
options.C: Asking the patient to perform the Valsalva manouvre and see if the pessary is in place
options.D: Being able to admit two fingers between the ring and the pessary.

questions.explanation: The first step after fitting the pessary to check if the pessary is adequately retained is to ask thepatient to perform Valsalva's maneuver or cough and see if the pessary is in place.There is some level of descent of the pessary with these maneuvers is to be expected, but thepessary should return to its normal position when these efforts are stopped. If the pessarydescends to the introitus with these maneuvers, then a larger size pessary should be tried.The pessary is well-fitted if you are able to slide the ring of the pessary up and down along thevaginal sidewall. It is well-fitted if you are able to insert one finger between the vaginal sidewalland the edge of the pessary. When the labia are separated, a well-supported pessary is not usuallyvisible.610The patient should be comfortable, and able to void urine with the pessary in place before leavingthe clinic.Types of pessariesDoughnut pessaryRing pessary with supportGellhorn pessaryCOMARROW

questions.question: The deepest part of perineal body injury, which causes cystocoele, enterocoele and urethraldescent is
questions.explanation: Pubococcygeus is the deepest part of the levator ani muscle. Injury to it can cause enterocele,cystocele, and urethral descent.Levator ani muscles are the most important muscles in the pelvic floor and maintain a constantstate of contraction. They provide a stable floor and support the weight of the abdominopelviccontents against intra-abdominal forces. Weakening of levator ani and pelvic fascia fromstretching or tearing during childbirth, may decrease support for the vagina, bladder, uterus, orrectum or alter the position of the neck of the bladder and urethra.The levator ani muscle is a complex unit, which consists of 3 muscle components namely•⚫ Pubococcygeus (anterior fibers)⚫ Pubovaginalis - elevates the urethra and hence contributes to urinary continence••⚫ Puboperinealis - draws the perineal body towards the pubic symphysis•⚫ Puboanalis elevates the anus and keeps the urogenital hiatus narrowed•Puborectalis (intermediate fibers)• Iliococcygeus (posterior fibers)Origin: The levator ani muscle has a linear origin from the pelvic surface of the body of the pubis,a tendinous arch of obturator fascia, and the pelvic surface of the ischial spine.Insertion:• The anterior fibres form a sling around the prostate (levator prostatae) or vagina (sphinctervaginae) and are inserted into the perineal body (a mass of fibrous tissue) in front of the analcanal.611• The intermediate fibres (puborectalis) form a sling around the anorectal junction to be insertedinto the anococcygeal raphe (a fibrous raphe which extends from the anorectal junction to the tipof the coccyx).•⚫ The posterior fibres (iliococcygeus) are inserted into the anococcygeal raphe and the coccyx.Nerve supply:• perineal branch of 4th sacral nerve (S4) from its pelvic surface.•⚫ perineal branch of the pudendal nerve (S2, S3) from its perineal surface.Actions:•The levator ani muscles of two sides together support the pelvic viscera and resist theintra-abdominal pressure during straining and expulsive efforts of the anterior abdominal wallmuscles.•They also subserve a sphincteric action on the anorectal junction to maintain the continence offaeces in both sexes and vagina in females.UrethralcanalVaginal canal(females only)Rectal canalSacrumPubic crestIliacusIliac crestsPelvic diaphragm (superior view)The given image below shows the pelvic floor:-PubococcygeusIliococcygeusLevator ani612Endopelvicfascia lining superioraspect of deepperineal space/pouch.UrethraVaginaRectumPubococcygeusIliococcygeus.IschiococcygeusPiriformisAnococcygeal ligamentPelvic floor0OMARROWPubic symphysisPubisTendinous archof levator aniFascia overobturatorinternusIschiumIliac wingThird and fourthsacral foraminaSacrum

questions.question: All of the following are correctly matched regarding the management of prolapse except

options.B: Vaginal pessary is contraindicated in pregnancy-
options.C: Postnatal Ring pessary and pelvic floor exercises for 3-6 months
options.D: Woman beyond 40 years and multipara - Vaginal hysterectomy and pelvic floor repair

questions.explanation: The vaginal pessary is not contraindicated in pregnancy.During pregnancy, depending on the severity and patient preference, prolapse is managedconservatively as follows:• Intravaginal pessaries - simple, effective, potentially effective in preventing preterm birth• Pelvic floor exercises• Pelvic physiotherapy• Electrical therapy

questions.question: 597All of the following surgeries are done in vault prolapse except
questions.explanation: Colposuspension is done in stress urinary incontinence and not for vault prolapse.Management of Vault prolapse:• If the patient is fit for abdominal surgery: Transabdominal sacral colpopexy, i.e., uterosacralsuspension•The best method for vault prolapse..• If the patient is not fit for abdominal surgery: Transvaginal sacrospinous ligament fixation.613
